title: About Me
text:
My name is Gloria Sunderland, and I’m a first-year Ph.D. student in Animal Sciences at the University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign (UIUC). My current research, under the guidance of Professor Rodriguez Zas, explores the influence of morphine and sex on genetic expression in the hypothalamus.
Outside of the lab, I love going for walks, knitting/ crocheting, and recently diving into cooking.

title: Consumption of Alcohol in Russia
text:
Data Source: https://www.kaggle.com/datasets/scibearia/consumption-of-alcohol-in-russia-2017-2023

Data Description: Data set includes alcohol consumption information across the years 2017-2023 for different alcohol types including wine, beer, vodka, sparkling wine, brandy, cider, liqueurs.

Research Questions

How has the consumption of different types of alcohol changed over time in Russia?
Can the consumption of one type of alcohol (ex. vodka) predict the consumption of other types (ex. beer, wine, or total alcohol)?


Research Question 1

Data visualization









Figure 1. Line plot of trends in Alcohol Consumption in Russia (2017–2023) across all alcohol types show that beer consumption remains consistently high with only a slight upward trend over time, with the other alcohol types appearing stable across time.










Figure 2. Trends in Alcohol Consumption in Russia (2017–2023), excluding beer, highlight a very slight increase in the consumption of vodka, wine, and liqueuers. Other alcohol types, such as sparkling wine and cider, show minimal changes.




Research Question 2

Data Visualization









Figure 3. Scatter plot showing relationship between vodka and beer consumption. A positive trend here suggests that higher consumption of vodka is associated with higher beer consumption. This suggests a relationship between the consumption of different types of alcohol. However, statistical analysis is needed to fully understand the nature of this relationship.



Correlation Matrix









Figure 4. Correlation matrix showing the relationships between different alcohol beverages. There are strong positive correlations between wine and sparkling wine (0.82), brandy and sparkling wine (0.87), and vodka and brandy (0.76), suggesting that higher consumption of one is associated with higher consumption of the other. Moderate correlations are also present between beer and other alcohol types, such as vodka (0.68).



Statistical Analysis



Call:
lm(formula = Total.alcohol.consumption..in.liters.of.pure.alcohol.per.capita. ~ 
    Vodka + Beer + Wine, data = Russia_data)

Residuals:
     Min       1Q   Median       3Q      Max 
-1.10772 -0.13759  0.01251  0.14529  0.73872 

Coefficients:
             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
(Intercept) 0.0278246  0.0269928   1.031    0.303    
Vodka       0.4724764  0.0053965  87.552   <2e-16 ***
Beer        0.0559735  0.0007427  75.361   <2e-16 ***
Wine        0.3270103  0.0078312  41.757   <2e-16 ***
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

Residual standard error: 0.224 on 591 degrees of freedom
Multiple R-squared:  0.9917,    Adjusted R-squared:  0.9917 
F-statistic: 2.353e+04 on 3 and 591 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16


Model 1. Linear regression model predicting total alcohol consumption based on vodka, beer, and wine consumption. The results indicate that vodka consumption has the strongest positive relationship with total alcohol consumption (coefficient = 0.47), followed by wine (0.33) and beer (0.056). The model explains 99.17% of the variance in total alcohol consumption (R-squared = 0.9917), demonstrating an excellent fit. All predictors are statistically significant, highlighting their importance in driving total alcohol consumption.

title: Student Depression Dataset
text:
Student Depression Dataset
Data Source: https://www.kaggle.com/datasets/hopesb/student-depression-dataset/data

Data Description/ Variables of Interest:

ID: Unique Student Identifier
Age: Age of student
Gender: Gender of student (Male, Female)
CGPA: Grade Point Average, or measure of Academic Success
Sleep Duration: Average daily sleep duration
Academic Pressure: Scale from 1 (least pressure) to 5 (most pressure)
Study Satisfaction: Scale from 1 (least satisfied) to 5 (most satisfied)
Depression: Does the student feel depressed (Yes/No)


Research Question: How do sleep duration and academic pressure affect CGPA and study satisfaction among students?



1. Preparing the data & Visualizing the variables









Figure 1. Box plot showing the distribution of CGPA across sleep duration categories. There is no clear relationship, as the median CGPA stays relatively consistent across all sleep duration groups. This suggests that sleep duration may not have a strong impact on CGPA.









Figure 2. Scatter plot showing relationship between academic pressure and CGPA. There appears to be a slight trend, with higher academic pressure associated with slightly lower CGPA, although the pattern is not strong.



2. Statistical Analysis

Correlation Matrix









Figure 3. Correlation matrix showing relationship between variables of interest: Academic Pressure, CGPA, Study Satisfaction, and Sleep Duration. The values range from -1 to 1 (with 0 indicating no correlation). The matrix shows weak correlations among the variables. Academic Pressure stands out as it has a slight negative correlation with Study Satisfaction (-0.11) and CGPA (-0.02).



Linear Regression
Model 1. Linear regression to predict CGPA from Sleep duration and Academic pressure.



Call:
lm(formula = CGPA ~ Sleep.Duration + Academic.Pressure, data = data)

Residuals:
    Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
-7.7639 -1.3519  0.1131  1.2642  2.4388 

Coefficients:
                                 Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
(Intercept)                      7.763893   0.027312 284.266  < 2e-16 ***
Sleep.Duration7-8 hours         -0.002731   0.025375  -0.108 0.914276    
Sleep.DurationLess than 5 hours -0.046314   0.024703  -1.875 0.060823 .  
Sleep.DurationMore than 8 hours -0.083029   0.026598  -3.122 0.001800 ** 
Sleep.DurationOthers            -0.092559   0.347012  -0.267 0.789677    
Academic.Pressure               -0.023930   0.006378  -3.752 0.000176 ***
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

Residual standard error: 1.47 on 27892 degrees of freedom
Multiple R-squared:  0.0009943, Adjusted R-squared:  0.0008152 
F-statistic: 5.552 on 5 and 27892 DF,  p-value: 4.078e-05


This linear regression model looks at the relationship between CGPA, Sleep Duration, and Academic Pressure.
The intercept suggests that students with the reference Sleep Duration (5-6 hours) and no Academic Pressure have an average CGPA of 7.76. Sleep Duration categories mostly do not significantly impact CGPA, except for ‘More than 8 hours,’ which is associated with a significant decrease of 0.083 in CGPA (p = 0.0018).
Academic Pressure shows a small but significant negative effect on CGPA, with every one-unit increase associated with a decrease of 0.024 (p = 0.0002).
Importantly, the model explains only less than 0.1% of the variation in CGPA (R-squared = 0.0009943), meaning that other variables not included in the model play a more substantial role in predicting CGPA.

Model 2. Linear regression to predict Study Satisfaction from Sleep duration and Academic pressure



Call:
lm(formula = Study.Satisfaction ~ Sleep.Duration + Academic.Pressure, 
    data = data)

Residuals:
    Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
-3.3075 -0.9804  0.0365  1.0545  2.2726 

Coefficients:
                                 Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
(Intercept)                      3.290638   0.025132 130.935   <2e-16 ***
Sleep.Duration7-8 hours         -0.009593   0.023349  -0.411    0.681    
Sleep.DurationLess than 5 hours -0.018026   0.022731  -0.793    0.428    
Sleep.DurationMore than 8 hours  0.016830   0.024475   0.688    0.492    
Sleep.DurationOthers             0.165757   0.319311   0.519    0.604    
Academic.Pressure               -0.109037   0.005869 -18.578   <2e-16 ***
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

Residual standard error: 1.353 on 27892 degrees of freedom
Multiple R-squared:  0.01244,   Adjusted R-squared:  0.01226 
F-statistic: 70.26 on 5 and 27892 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16


This linear regression model looks at the relationship between Study Satisfaction, Sleep Duration, and Academic Pressure. The intercept indicates that students with the reference Sleep Duration (5-6 hours) and no Academic Pressure have an average Study Satisfaction score of 3.29.
Sleep Duration categories do not significantly affect Study Satisfaction, as none of the categories show significant p-values. Academic Pressure, however, has a substantial and significant negative effect on Study Satisfaction, with each one-unit increase in Academic Pressure associated with a decrease of 0.109 in Study Satisfaction (p < 2e-16).
This model explains only 1.2% of the variation in Study Satisfaction (R-squared = 0.01244), meaning that other factors not included in the model contribute significantly to variations in Study Satisfaction.
